article_title: Book Review: 'Hell Before Breakfast' by Robert H. Patton
article_text: On Jan. 29, 1855, the British House of Commons voted to establish a select committee to look into the government's conduct of the Crimean War. The prime minister, the Earl of Aberdeen, regarded this as a vote of no confidence and immediately resigned. It was perhaps the first time in history that a government had fallen for a reason other than an election, royal displeasure or a coup. Instead, Aberdeen found himself out of a job because of the dispatches sent from the front by reporter William Howard Russell of the Times of...

article_summary:
Instead, Aberdeen found himself out of a job because of the dispatches sent from the front by reporter William Howard Russell of the Times of...
The prime minister, the Earl of Aberdeen, regarded this as a vote of no confidence and immediately resigned.
On Jan. 29, 1855, the British House of Commons voted to establish a select committee to look into the government's conduct of the Crimean War.
It was perhaps the first time in history that a government had fallen for a reason other than an election, royal displeasure or a coup.
